conclusion: Work Done by an Ideal Gas in a Thermodynamic Cycle
Looking at the images, I can see a rectangular ABCDA cycle in the P-V diagram for an ideal gas: - A at point (V_1, P_1) - B at point (V_1, P_2) - C at point (V_2, P_2) - D at point (V_2, P_1)
The question asks for the work done by the gas when transitioning from state D to state A.
From the P-V diagram, the transition from D to A is a horizontal line from (V_2, P_1) to (V_1, P_1). This represents an isobaric process (constant pressure).
For any process, the work done by a gas is given by: W = ∫ P dV

premise: In an isobaric process, pressure is constant (P = P_1).
Since V_1 < V_2 (we're moving from right to left on the diagram), (V_1 - V_2) is negative.
conclusion: When a gas is compressed (volume decreases), work is done ON the gas by the surroundings, not BY the gas. So the work done BY the gas is negative: W_{D → A} = P_1 (V_1 - V_2) = -P_1 (V_2 - V_1)

premise: The work done by the gas on the surroundings when transitioning from state D to state A is: W_{D → A} = -P_1 (V_2 - V_1)
conclusion: This is negative, indicating that work is done ON the gas, not BY the gas during this compression process.
